abstract: One analyst thinks that Microsoft may be motivated to top Google’s $12.5 billion deal for Motorola. But there are many concerns that have to be considered.
snippet: One analyst thinks that Microsoft may be motivated to top Google’s $12.5 billion deal for Motorola. But there are many concerns that have to be considered.
lead_paragraph: Ted S. Warren/Associated PressA Windows Phone 7 at a Microsoft store.

headline.main: Musing on the Prospects of a Microsoft Counterbid for Motorola

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: As Google moves to buy Motorola Mobility, RIM, already under pressure from declining market share, is still an attractive prospect for takeover.
snippet: As Google moves to buy Motorola Mobility, RIM, already under pressure from declining market share, is still an attractive prospect for takeover.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Ever since the introduction of its first BlackBerry more than a decade ago, Research in Motion has defied expectations that it would be gobbled up by a larger rival and has effectively created the market for smartphones.

headline.main: BlackBerry Maker RIM Again Subject of Takeover Talk

abstract: The price Hewlett-Packard paid for Palm last year now looks cheap. But it could be difficult for H.P. to cash in.
snippet: The price Hewlett-Packard paid for Palm last year now looks cheap. But it could be difficult for H.P. to cash in.
lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard’s $1.2 billion acquisition of Palm last year suddenly looks smarter. Google’s $12.5 billion deal to buy Motorola Mobility this week, and the earlier frenzied bidding for Nortel’s patents, have revealed the riches in mobile computing intellectual property. And H.P. snatched one of the most important troves for a price that now looks cheap. Yet, it could be challenging for H.P. to cash in.

headline.main: H.P.-Palm Deal Looks Better With Time

byline.original: By Robert Cyran and Agnes T. Crane

abstract: Wall Street is looking at other companies with large mobile patent portfolios as possible targets for licensing deals or takeovers after Google bid $12.5 billion for Motorola Mobililty.
snippet: Wall Street is looking at other companies with large mobile patent portfolios as possible targets for licensing deals or takeovers after Google bid $12.5 billion for Motorola Mobililty.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street bankers and technology executives have been busy with their calculators in the wake of Google’s $12.5 billion offer for Motorola Mobililty.

headline.main: Quest for Patents Brings New Focus in Tech Deals

abstract: Recent blockbuster patent deals are fed largely by legal considerations, not economic ones, analysts say.
snippet: Recent blockbuster patent deals are fed largely by legal considerations, not economic ones, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: Google was willing on Monday to pay $12.5 billion for Motorola Mobility in no small part because of its stockpile of 17,000 patents. The patent portfolio, some analysts estimate, could represent more than half of the value of the deal, or more than $400,000 a patent.

headline.main: A Bull Market in Tech Patents
headline.print_headline: A Bull Market in Tech Patents
